div.p: Rothberger, Alfred (1873–1932), Austrian tailor and businessman; one of the four sons of the Viennese garment manufacturer Jakob Rothberger. After the death of his father in 1899, together with his brothers Moritz and Heinrich he took over the paternal firm. The „Rothberger Geschäftshäuser“ [Rothberger houses of business] were located on the Stephansplatz at Nos. 1 and 9–11.

Clearly, Alfred Rothberger, like his brother Moritz, who was also a professional sculptor, was artistically gifted, too, and created medallions. A bronze medallion portrait of Schenker survives as OJ 73/2 (photograph as OJ 72/14, No. 18), with the names „Heinrich Schenker” and „Alfred Rothberger” inscribed on the mold. Moreover, Alfred Rothberger created a plaque of the respected singing teacher Otto Iro (1890–1971) and a medallion bearing the portrait of the composer Gustav Mahler.
Schenker gave lessons to an „A. Rothberger” in 1934–35, for which monthly accounts survive (OC A/260r).

Rothberger, Hilda (Hilde), wife of Alfred Rothberger, with whom she had two sons and a daughter. There is substantial correspondence from Hilda Rothberger to Heinrich and Jeanette Schenker dating between 1929 and 1938 (OJ 13/31, OC 38/489, 44/34–35, A/295).

Edith Hann, Herrenkleider-Magazin Jacob Rothberger, in: Andreas Lehne, Wiener Warenhäuser 1865–1914, with contributions by Gerhard Meißl and Edith Hann (Forschungen und Beiträge zur Wiener Stadtgeschichte 20, Vienna 1990), pp. 85–122.
Das Jahrbuch der Wiener Gesellschaft 1928, ed. Franz Planer (Vienna 1928), p. 286.
Felix Czeike, Historisches Lexikon Wien, vol. 4 (Vienna 1995), p. 704.
Federhofer, Heinrich Schenker nach Tagebüchern und Briefen... (Hildesheim: Georg Olms, 1985), p. 76.
